title: Content Restructuring and Expansion Prompt
description: Guidelines for expanding and restructuring educational blog posts to match a consistent, classroom-focused tone and format.
kramdown_requirements: Use fenced code blocks with language specification (~~~ language or ```language)
No bare URLs—wrap in descriptive link text [description](url)
Proper list formatting with consistent indentation and blank lines before/after lists
Inline images with descriptive alt text: ![alt text](/path/to/image.png)
Use <!--more--> excerpt separator after introductory content
Proper YAML frontmatter with excerptSeparator, date, categories, tags, and search metadata

restructuring_steps.name: Reorganize opening
restructuring_steps.description: Introduce foundational value propositions before diving into technical features
sub_points: Add 'Why [tool/concept] helps' section with 3-4 bullet points addressing student/teacher pain points
Add 'What students gain' section with learning outcomes and benefits
Clarify the 'Features' section with concise, benefit-driven descriptions
Maintain the original problem statement but strengthen its connection to the solution

restructuring_steps.name: Add classroom use cases
restructuring_steps.description: Provide concrete, real-world scenarios teachers will recognize
sub_points: Include 4-5 specific use cases (e.g., braille progress tracking, assistive-tech monitoring, session notes)
Frame each use case with practical outcomes (e.g., 'weekly fluency checks', 'configuration tracking')
Reference specific skills or tools mentioned in the original content (e.g., Perkins braillewriter, place-value alignment)
Make each use case immediately actionable for educators

restructuring_steps.name: Add teaching tips
restructuring_steps.description: Offer practical strategies for effective classroom implementation
sub_points: Provide 4-5 actionable, classroom-tested recommendations
Use imperative language (e.g., 'Make entries immediately', 'Be consistent with entry types')
Connect tips to earlier use cases and features so advice feels integrated
Include tips for both foundational use and advanced refinement (e.g., 'Check work using frames', 'Gradually fade structure')

restructuring_steps.name: Reformat example images
restructuring_steps.description: Integrate images with inline descriptions for clarity and accessibility
sub_points: Convert bullet lists of images to inline format with descriptive labels
Include alt text that describes both the component and notation (e.g., 'Addition/Subtraction Frame (UEB braille)')
Maintain file paths and ensure images are accessible in the site structure
Use proper Kramdown image syntax: ![alt text](/assets/images/path/to/image.png)

restructuring_steps.name: Streamline advanced customization
restructuring_steps.description: Make technical customization accessible without overwhelming detail
sub_points: Replace lengthy technical code blocks with clear, numbered steps
Link to external tools and resources (e.g., OpenSCAD.org, slicing software) rather than duplicating instructions
Separate basic customization (using UI controls) from advanced customization (editing source code)
Defer complex details to the README in the download package
Maintain reference links but avoid multi-page technical instructions inline

restructuring_steps.name: Expand contribution note
restructuring_steps.description: Invite specific types of contributions aligned with the post's goals
sub_points: Ask for contributions that extend the tool's usefulness (custom templates, lesson plans, assessment rubrics, export scripts)
Emphasize open-source collaboration and community benefit
Reference GitHub issues and pull requests as contribution channels
Match the tone to earlier sections (practical, classroom-focused, collaborative)

restructuring_steps.name: Remove or consolidate extraneous elements
restructuring_steps.description: Clean up elements that don't serve the post's purpose
sub_points: Remove static HTML form includes (e.g., {% include staticman-form.html %})
Remove overly technical implementation notes that don't aid classroom use
Consolidate redundant explanations or tool descriptions
Ensure all remaining content directly supports teachers or developers using the tool

primary_characteristics: Classroom-focused: written for teachers, TVIs, and educators, not software engineers
Practical and actionable: every section should offer something teachers can immediately apply
Humble and collaborative: invite feedback, acknowledge limitations, welcome contributions
Consistent technical precision: maintain correct terminology (e.g., UEB vs. Nemeth, OpenSCAD, Kramdown)
Encouraging: emphasize what students gain and how the tool reduces cognitive burden
language_patterns: Use short, direct sentences (aim for 12-15 word average)
Prefer active voice ('students practice long division' vs. 'long division can be practiced')
Use imperatives for actionable advice ('Make entries immediately', 'Be consistent')
Use parallel structure in lists and use cases for readability
Avoid marketing hype—focus on concrete benefits and honest limitations
Do not use em-dash or en-dash
Use the Oxford comma for all lists as applicable

section_order: [Additional sections as relevant to tool: Data export, Customization, etc.]
[NO static form includes or extraneous markup]

formatting: Blank lines before and after headings
Fenced code blocks with language tags (~~~language)
Backtics (```) in kramdown reference block/quote text and not languaged tagged code
No bare URLs—always wrap in link text [description](url)
Proper blank lines around lists (before and after)
kramdown_checklist.validation_step: Run `jekyll build --future` or linting check to confirm no Markdown errors (MD022, MD003, etc.)

example_usage.input: A minimally structured blog post with technical details mixed into narrative
example_usage.process: Apply the 7 restructuring steps above while maintaining Kramdown compatibility
example_usage.output: A classroom-ready, well-organized post with clear sections, actionable advice, and community contribution pathway

notes: This prompt is designed for educational content about instructional tools, assistive technology, or pedagogy.
The tone and structure prioritize teacher usability over technical completeness.
Always maintain subject-matter accuracy while improving clarity and accessibility.
Contributions and feedback on this prompt are welcome—this is a living document.
